1600/A0/04/002/002.status_value: The legislative package related to strengthening legal protection of children from violence was adopted by the Parliament and as a result ten different laws were amended. The Law on Early and Pre-school Education was initiated at the Parliament for further discussion. Other important legislative initiatives being advocated for include the Juvenile Justice Code  the Law on Adoption and Foster Care  a legislative package on documentation/identification for children living and/or working on the str
1600/A0/04/002/002.indicator_name: Number of legislative and policy initiatives formally initiated and influenced by civil society

1600/A0/04/002/001.indicator_name: % of public believing that social benefits to families with children generate dependency

Relevant government authority reports twice a year to Ministry/Parliament on the results achieved by the national law/strategy/policy  based on monitoring plan with basic indicators  disaggregated by region and population group and baselines (based on a nationally representative survey)

1.      Law/regulation/by-law supporting social protection benefits and/or services for children  is drafted and approved   2. Existing strategic documents explicitly identify children as one of the priority groups and detail specific actions to reach them

1.      Total expenditure on social protection in % of GDP/State Budget ¿ compared with regional average  EU or OECD average (WB database)   2. Share of the total SP expenditure going to child benefits.

1. A unified database collecting information on children sho are beneficiaries of social protection and other social programmes i exists and is used by the relevant Ministry and covers the entire country (administrative data)  2. A reference mechanism adopted by the Social Service Agency and officially integrated into its Database of Socially Vulnerable Families.
Ratio of children receiving Targeted Social assistance vs. Children living in poverty.
1.share of out of pocket health expenditures  2.share of out of pocket education expenditures
Share of the partner ministries using integrated and desegregated data for policies  allocating budgets and monitoring progress in alleviation of social exclusion and child poverty
1600/A0/04/002/001.baseline_value: 3 out of 6 Ministries (6 Ministries - MoLHSA  MoES  MoJ  MRA  MoYS  MoF)

1600/A0/04/001/001.indicator_name: % of children 3-5 whose primary caregivers report "s/he is too young" and "child is better raised at home" as the reasons for non attending preschool
Status of establishment of a central coordination and monitoring body on preschool education
Percentage of municipalities with adequate funding allocated per child aged 3-5 years old
Number of municipalities that have adopted a Preschool Education Strategy
Proportion of preschools with a minimum early stimulation material package available
Percentage of caregivers/pre-school teachers trained on preschool education
% of children age 3-5 whose primary caregivers report financial barriers as a reason for not attending pre-school
Number municipalities that adopted existing standards and guidelines of preschool services
Number of municipalities where at least 70% of required pre-school places are available for children aged 3-5
% of poorest municipalities (bottom 20%) providing inclusive education in line with national standards

1600/A0/04/001/003.indicator_name: % financial resources reallocated from residential institutions to community based alternative care and protection services
Proportion of the population who perceive that others have a positive attitude towards children living with a disability
Revision of existing adoption and foster care legislation supportive to the deinstitutionalization process
The Social Service Agency (SSA) budget includes a line item for vouchers for early interventions for children with disabilities age 0-6 years old
Social agents' Child Assessment Tool adopted by the Social Service Agency
Percentage of planned (currently 12) small group homes to de-institutionalize children with disabilities which have been established
Percentage of TSA beneficiaries which are children
Percentage of social work professionals who believe that institutional care is an appropriate response to children with disability
Proportion of social workers whose performance is evaluated by senior social workers each year

1600/A0/04/001/002.indicator_name: 1.10 visits of a healthy child are fully utilized  2. Increased PHC utilization rate  related to child health problem management by 20%

1. There are internal quality control mechanisms at medical facilities  2. External quality control is elaborated at the state level and implemented throughout the country  3. Retraining of the medical personnel delivering MCH care services is carried out
Share of public health care funding is increased in the healthcare budget

1. There is a strategic document which determines health priorities in the country  2. PHC regulatory mechanisms are in place (these mechanisms include: human resources  respective legislative acts  normatives/ordinances)  3. The bylaws ensuring BMS code monitoring are inforced  4. The regulation is in place for the introduction of regionalized perinatal care in Georgia

1. State regulates relations between PHC and maternity  2. The patronage system for children is revived  3. Medical assignments within the State programmes are clearly articulated  which are based on the unified/national standards of medical service provision

The list of essential drugs for children (to be provided for free) comprises the medicines for the management of childhood illnesses as well as the supplements ensuring child growth and development (2-24 months)

1. Passportization of medical facilities across the country is carried out  to determine the problems related to accessibility (geographical  HR etc.)  2.  The official webpage of NCDCPH integrates knowledge hub/library  which stores constantly updated information for the public  3. Capacity is developed for early identification of children with developmental problems  referral and management
Universal health care for mothers and children in Georgia is introduced

1. The special funding is allocated to the parenting education in the state health budget  2. NCDCPH actively implements public awareness programs  3. Information materials are available in the languages of main ethnic minorities
Different levels of MCH care are linked via the MCHMIS ensuring the continuity of care

1600/A0/04/001/002.status_value: Due to the introduction of universal health insurance 100 % of population are aware of available MCH services.
1600/A0/04/001/002.indicator_name: % of poorest quintile are aware of available maternal and child health services and are able to access them
% of MCH facilities/maternities applying approved WHO standards

1600/A0/04/001/002.status_value: Due to the introduction of universal health insurance 100 % of representatives of minority groups are aware of available MCH services.
1600/A0/04/001/002.indicator_name: By 2015 % of two main minority groups are aware of available maternal and child health services and are able to access them
1600/A0/04/001/002.baseline_value: 50% in Kvemo Kartli and 42.3% in Samtskhe Javakheti aware (National Average 58.6%)

1600/A0/05/881/001.headline: In an effort to reduce mother and child mortality  UNICEF Georgia supported the Government to systematically introduce the regionalization of perinatal care and a new maternal and child health electronic surveillance system.

1600/A0/05/881/001.status_value: 120 medical professionals trained on some aspects of IMCI (immunization  child development monitoring  breast feeding diarrhoea infections) and 14 medical professionals participating in study visit to Kazakhstan to learn about introduction of IMCI
1600/A0/05/881/001.indicator_name: Primary Health Care facilities providing clinical care to children under five using the IMNCI approach

1600/A0/05/881/001.target_value: 90% (ca. 200) of PHC medical professionals in Abkhazia fully trained on IMCI

1600/A0/05/881/001.status_value: E-module surveillance system that registers every pregnant in Georgia and tracks them throughout the pregnancy and delivery care  became operational with UNICEF support from January 2016.
1600/A0/05/881/001.indicator_name: Health Management Information System generates periodic reports with data disaggregated by age and sex (for relevant indicators) at national and sub-national level

1600/A0/05/881/002.headline: In order to promote healthy child growth  development and protection for young children (0-3 years of age)  UNICEF Georgia supported the Government to establish comprehensive home-visiting  child nutrition and immunization services.
1600/A0/05/881/002.target_value: Home visiting policy is in use

1600/A0/05/881/003.status_value: The law was adopted in June 2016

1600/A0/05/883/002.status_value: Staff of regional centers of PDO were trained on child rights monitoring.
1600/A0/05/883/002.indicator_name: "(DEACTIVATED Jan 1 2017) Existence of Ombudsmans Office  National Human Rights Instititution  or a network of child rights civil society groups that are able to monitor and report on child rights violations "
1600/A0/05/883/002.headline: With UNICEF Georgia's support  independent child rights monitoring mechanisms were reinforced in the Georgia context.
1600/A0/05/883/002.baseline_value: A specific centre for children rights exists within the Ombudsman Office but its capacities need to be significantly reinforced as regards to monitoring  analysing and reporting child rights violations.
1600/A0/05/883/002.target_value: The Child Rights Centre of the Public Defender Office applies fully the Paris Principles (national institutions for the protection and promotion of Human Rights)

1600/A0/05/883/002.indicator_name: Existence of Ombudsmans Office  National Human Rights Institution  or a network of child rights civil society groups that are able to monitor and report on child rights violations
1600/A0/05/883/002.headline: With UNICEF Georgia's support  independent child rights monitoring mechanisms were reinforced in the Georgia context.

1600/A0/05/883/001.indicator_name: National rule of law  access to justice  justice sector reform policies  strategies and plans (or equivalent) incorporate issues pertaining to children's equitable access to justice - children well included in all key strategies and plans  partially  children are included in some key strategies and plans or/and not in a comprehensive manner
1600/A0/05/883/001.headline: In order to ensure that children have access to child friendly justice system  UNICEF Georgia supported the implementation of the Juvenile Justice Code  including the specialisation of justice professionals  the establishment of a child-friendly environment and the creation of a comprehensive data collection system.
1600/A0/05/883/001.baseline_value: Procedures and services exist in the criminal justice system (JJ code) only and would need to be strengthened. Procedures and services to be developed for the civil and administrative justice system

1600/A0/05/883/001.status_value: The concept was developed and will be validated in January 2017
1600/A0/05/883/001.indicator_name: Existence of procedures and services for children in contact with law that are applied and delivered in line with international norms
1600/A0/05/883/001.headline: In order to ensure that children have access to child friendly justice system  UNICEF Georgia supported the implementation of the Juvenile Justice Code  including the specialisation of justice professionals  the establishment of a child-friendly environment and the creation of a comprehensive data collection system.
1600/A0/05/883/001.baseline_value: Procedures and services exist in the criminal justice system (JJ code) only and would need to be strengthened. Procedures and services to be developed for the civil and administrative justice system
1600/A0/05/883/001.target_value: All children in contact with the justice system benefit from child friendly procedures and services in line with international standards

1600/A0/05/882/003.status_value: State committed additional vouchers to daycare center services in Samtskhe Javakheti and to Small scale Alternative Care Facility in Kutaisi  Imereti Region.
1600/A0/05/882/003.indicator_name: (DEACTIVATED Jan 1 2017) Child Protection system has both preventive and responsive services available and there is a framework for coordination
1600/A0/05/882/003.headline: In order to ensure a supportive family-environment for every child and bolster progress towards building child-friendly social services  UNICEF Georgia supported the Government to strengthen the national child protection system  and to enhance the access and quality of general education for most vulnerable children in Georgia.
1600/A0/05/882/003.baseline_value: Responsive services are unevenly available throughout the country (urban/rural)  some preventive services are available but would need to be expanded and broadened (violence  street children  etc.). The framework for cooperation exists (through in particular regional panels) but would need to be strengthened to be effective
1600/A0/05/882/003.target_value: Responsive services are evenly distributed throughout the country  preventive services exists and the framework for collaboration is effective

1600/A0/05/882/003.status_value: Total number of social workers (at Social Service Agency and National Probation Agency) is 290.  3 SWs were added to NPA and 15 - to SSA.

1600/A0/05/882/002.status_value: Verbal agreement has been reached with the NSO (National Statistics Office) to adjust the data gathering according to the child age groups as defined by UNICEF. Further collaboration is needed to agree on production of the child poverty disaggregated data.

1600/A0/05/882/002.headline: In order to reduce vulnerability and promote social inclusion of children  UNICEF Georgia in partnership with Government oversaw the implementation of the TSA reform and advocated for the expansion of child-benefits.
1600/A0/05/882/002.target_value: National Statistics Office annually monitors and publishes child poverty disaggregated data by age  geographical location  sex and ethnicity

1600/A0/05/882/001.status_value: First draft of the mapping produced  under negotiation with the Ministry to be finalized in 2017

1600/A0/05/882/001.headline: To support the development and revision of legislation and policies for building a child-friendly social protection system  UNICEF Georgia contributed to the generation of strategic evidence on equity gaps and social norms and continued advocacy and policy dialogue for the reduction of child poverty.

1600/A0/05/882/001.target_value: Comprehensive national social protection system covering multiple deprivations of excluded children is existent
